add_atom(symbol, position)[source]¶

add an atom to the structure

Checks to see if an existing atom exists at the position we are trying to add an atom, then if the position is empty. The atom is added then added to the list of interstitials.

Parameters

  • symbol (str) – the symbol of the atom to be added

  • position (str) – the position of the atom to be added

Raises

ValueError – If an atom already exists in the position.

pypospack.crystal module¶

Crystallographic classes and methods for pypospack.

This module represents simulation cells are crystallographic representions and classes and methods to support this represention.

class pypospack.crystal.RadialDistributionFunction[source]¶

Bases: object

pairCorrelationFunction_3D(y, z, S, rMax, dr)[source]¶

Compute the three-dimensioanl pair correlation function

Compute the three-dimensional pair correlation function for a set of spherical particles contained in a cube with side length S. This simple function finds reference particles such that a sphere of radius rMax drawn around the particle will fit entirely within the cube, eliminating the need to compensate for edge effects. If no such particles exist, an error is returned. Try a smaller rMax…or write some code to handle edge effects! ;)

Parameters

  • x (numpy.ndarray) – an array of x positions of centers of particles

  • y (numpy.ndarray) – an array of y positions of centers of particles

  • z (numpy.ndarray) – an array of z positions of centers of particles

  • S (list) – length of each side of the cube in space

  • rMax (float) – outer diameter of largest spherical shell

  • dr (float) – increment for increasing radius of spherical shell

Returns

first element is a numpy array containing the correlation

function g(r) radii. the second element is a numpy array containing the radii of the spherical shells used to compute g(r). the final element are the indices of the refence particles

Return type

tuple

class pypospack.crystal.SimulationCell(obj=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A structural representation of a material system

A structural system consists of a vector of lattice vector which forms the boundaries of the simulation cell, and an atomic basis of atoms defined in the direct coordinates of the lattice vectors.

Parameters

obj (optional) – if this argument is set then the this constructor acts as a copy constructor. Will takse ase.atoms.Atoms and

comment¶

a descriptive description of the crystal structure

Type

str

atomic_basis¶

a list of atoms contained within the crystal structure.

Type

list of pypospack.crystallography.Atoms

a0¶

a scaling factor which scales the lattice vectors by a0. Default is 1.

Type

float

H¶

a numpy array containing the lattice vectors as row vectors. Default is [[1,0,0],[0,1,0],[0,0,1]]

Type

numpy.ndarray

ptol¶

tolerance in which to find an atom/layer. Defaults to None.

Type

float,optional

check_if_atom_exists_at_position(symbol, position)[source]¶

determines if there is an atom at a position

This code looks for atoms in the list of atoms in the atomic_basis.

Returns

The first element if true in an atom exists at the location,

False if it doesn’t exist. The second element is an int which indicates the index of the atom at that position. The index is negative if it is the list of interstitials.

Return type

tuple

pypospack.dft module¶

pypospack.dft

This is module for some functional utilies for DFT simulations

pypospack.dft.determine_kpoint_meshes(simulation_cell, rho_min=1, rho_max=10, d_rho=0.1, kpoint_min=3, kpoint_max=15)[source]¶
Parameters

  • simulation_cell (pypospack.crystal.SimulationCell) – The simulation cell in which to determine the kpoint density. Any class which subclasses pypospack.crystal.SimulationCell is usable.

  • rho_min (float) – lowest linear kpoint density to start. Default is 1.

  • rho_max (float) – largest linear kpoint density to end. Default is 10.

  • d_rho (float) – the size of the step of the linear kpoint density. Default is 0.1

  • kpoint_min (int) – Minimum number of kpoints in a linear direction. Default is 3, which is appropriate for approximately cubic crystals.

  • kpoint_max – Maximum number of kpoints is a linear direction. Default is 15, which is appropriate for approximately cubic crystals.

pypospack.dft.get_kpoint_mesh(simulation_cell, linear_kpoint_density)[source]¶

This function determines what the kpoint mesh should be given a linear kpoint density. This is inspired from the kpoint generation methodology of VASP.

Parameters

  • simulation_cell (pyflamestk.crystal.SimulationCell) –

  • linear_kpoint_density (str) –

Refs:

https://cms.mpi.univie.ac.at/vasp/vasp/Automatic_k_mesh_generation.html

class pypospack.eam.EamSetflFile[source]¶

Bases: object

class to deal with setfl files

SETFL files is a legacy file format for the distribution of EAM files which are necessary for many codes which use molecular dynamics.

Notes

class pypospack.eamtools.EamFuncflFile[source]¶

Bases: object

class pypospack.eamtools.EamSetflFile[source]¶

Bases: object

This class wites a setfl file.

There are three components to the EAM model: the embedding energy, the electron density, and interatomic pair potential. LAMMPS uses a very old format for reading/writing EAM files.

The potential functions are stored as they would be generated from their functional forms, in units eV. However, they are written to be compliant with the setfl format which requires the element to be stored as V(r)*r.

Both the electron density function and the potential energy has a physical requirement that V(r_cut) = 0 and rho(r_cut) = 0. The application of a cutoff function not implemented by this class, and it is responsibility of the code using this class to ensure this.

All units of measurement are in metal units. Distance being Angstroms, and energy being eV.

Parameters

None –

comments¶

The setfl file format has a three line comment section at the beginning of the file.

Type

list of str

filename¶

This is the filename to either read/write too.

Type

str

symbols¶

This is a list of symbols modelled by the Embedded Atom Model.

Type

list of str

n_symbols¶

This is the number of elements for the setfl file.

Type

int

N_r¶

The number of points sampled for the distance from the nuclei in the electron density function, or the distance between two atoms in pair potentials.

Type

int

N_rho¶

The number of points where the electron density is sampled.

Type

int

d_r¶

Distance between the point where the potential functions and the electron density function are evaluated.

Type

float

d_rho¶

Distance between the points where the delectron density is sampled.

Type

float

r¶

This is a :numpy.ndarray: array of possible evaluations from d_r to r_max with N_r intervals. It does not include r = 0.

Type

numpy.ndarray

rho¶

This is an :numpy.ndarray: array of possible evaluations from d_rho to rho_max with N_rho interals. It does not include rho = 0.

Type

numpy.ndarray

func_embedding¶

This is a dictionary containing the embedding function. The embedding function is indexed by elements in the symbols attribute. The embedding function is stored as an :numpy.ndarray: of length N_r. This attribute is initialized as None.

Type

OrderedDict

func_density¶

This is a dictionary containing the electron density function indexed by elements in the symbols attribute. The density function is stored as an :numpy.ndarray: of length N_r. This attribute is initialized as None.

Type

OrderedDict

func_pair_potential¶

They has the format ‘sym_i.sym_j’ which are generated from unique combinations from the symbols attribute. The pairs are selected as s_i, s_j in S, where i <= j. This attribute is initialized as none.

Type

OrderedDict

Ref:

https://sites.google.com/a/ncsu.edu/cjobrien/tutorials-and-guides/eam http://www.ctcms.nist.gov/potentials/ http://lammps.sandia.gov/doc/pair_eam.html

N_r
N_rho

process_setfl_header_section()[source]¶

Process the header section of the setfl file.

The header section consists of two sections

process_setfl_n_symbols()[source]¶
process_setfl_pairpotential_section()[source]¶

The SETFL convention for storing V(r) is as r*V(r). This was probably important during the time when computational cycles were expensive. However, we divide this storage value by r to get the potential in eV.

process_setfl_rho_r_args(string=None)[source]¶

pypospack.eipfit module¶

This module contains the pyposmat engine for parameterization

class pypospack.eipfit.EipFittingEngine(fname_config_pyposmat='pyposmat.config', fname_config_potential='pyposmat.potential', fname_config_qoi='pyposmat.qoi', fname_results='results.out', fname_log='pyposmat.log', random_seed=None, restart=False)[source]¶

Bases: object

Generic Fitting Engine

This fitting engine does not have an algorithm.

Parameters

  • fname_config_pyposmat (string) – filename of the configuration file. default is pyposmat.config

  • fname_config_potential (string) – filename of the potential file. default is pyposmat.potential

  • fname_config_qoi (string) – filename of the qoi file

  • random_seed (int) – random seed to use. Default is set to None, which generates the random seed automatically.

  • restart (bool) – when set to True, attempts to restart simulations from existing information contained in the directory

fname_config_pyposmat¶
Type

fname_config_potential¶
Type

str

fname_config_qoi¶
Type

str

random_seed¶
Type

restart¶
Type

exception pypospack.eipfit.EipFittingError[source]¶

pypospack.elements module¶

Properties of the chemical elements.

Each chemical element is represented as an object instance. Physicochemical and descriptive properties of the elements are stored as instance attributes.

Author

Christoph Gohlke

Version

2018.02.06

Requirements¶

  • CPython 2.7 or 3.6

Revisions¶

2018.02.06

Style and docstring fixes.

2016.02.25

Fixed some ionization energies.

References

  1. http://physics.nist.gov/PhysRefData/Compositions/

  2. http://physics.nist.gov/PhysRefData/IonEnergy/tblNew.html

  3. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%(element.name)s

  4. http://www.miranda.org/~jkominek/elements/elements.db

Examples

>>> from elements import ELEMENTS
>>> len(ELEMENTS)
109
>>> str(ELEMENTS[109])
'Meitnerium'
>>> ele = ELEMENTS['C']
>>> ele.number, ele.symbol, ele.name, ele.eleconfig
(6, 'C', 'Carbon', '[He] 2s2 2p2')
>>> from pprint import pprint
>>> pprint(ele.eleconfig_dict)
{(1, 's'): 2, (2, 'p'): 2, (2, 's'): 2}
>>> sum(ele.mass for ele in ELEMENTS)
14659.1115599
>>> for ele in ELEMENTS:
...     ele.validate()
...     ele = eval(repr(ele))

pypospack.pareto module¶

This module provides pareto calculation functions

Eugene J. Ragasa, University of Florida, developed the original version of this code. Dmitriy Morozov, Lawrence Berkeley Labs, provided speed ups for the Pareto versions of the code in Dec 2016.

pypospack.potfit module¶

This module contains the pyposmat engine for parameterization

The fitting engine is build in multiple class for managability of code and to divide the code into functionality. In general, there are classes which deal with reading/writing configuration files, classes to deal with determination of simulations to be run from the quantities of interest.

class pypospack.potfit.AbstractFittingEngine(fname_config_structures='pypospack.structure.yaml', fname_config_potential='pypospack.potential.yaml', fname_config_qoi='pypospack.qoi.yaml', fname_results='results.out', fname_log='pypospack.log', random_seed=None, restart=False)[source]¶

Bases: object

Generic Fitting Engine

This fitting engine does not have an algorithm.

Parameters

  • fname_config_pyposmat (string) – filename of the configuration file. default is pyposmat.config

  • fname_config_potential (string) – filename of the potential file. default is pyposmat.potential

  • fname_config_qoi (string) – filename of the qoi file

  • random_seed (int) – random seed to use. Default is set to None, which generates the random seed automatically.

  • restart (bool) – when set to True, attempts to restart simulations from existing information contained in the directory

fname_config_potential¶
Type

pypospack.statistics module¶

implementation of some statistical functions

This module implements some staistical tools which are not currently implemented in any widely deployed python package.

pypospack.statistics.kullbach_lieber_divergence(f, g, n)[source]¶

Calculate the Kullbach-Lieber Divergence between f and g

This functions does a monte carlo estimation of the Kullbach-Lieber divergence pre-metric between two probability distribution functions f and g.

Notes

for f and q, the following classes are supported. scipy.stats.kde.gaussian_kde

Parameters

  • f (scipy.stats.gaussian_kde) – A probability distribution function

  • g (scipy.stats.gaussian_kde) – A probability distribution function

  • n (int) – The number of sampling points

Returns

returns a both the KLD convergence value, and the estimated error of the KLD value

Return type

tuple

Raises

Run –

pypospack.util module¶

pypospack.util.tail(fname, n_lines, offset=None)[source]¶

replicates the tail command from unix like operations systems

Parameters

  • fname (str) – filename

  • n_lines (int) – the number of lines

Note

this is dependent upon the tail command in the unx operating system this should actually be rewritten as to be OS agnostic.
